title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund
Interview Descriptions: One short 30 minute interview with program staff. No curve balls. Be prepared to talk about your background, interest in the position, and issues the program cares about (such as US foreign policy towards Asia).
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

title: Trainee/Student Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund
Interview Descriptions: Was invited to interview with the project manager and the HR representative. The interview took about 30 minutes and was relatively informal. Standard questions about my interest and background. The entire process from application to selection took about one and a half months.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this role?

title: Project Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: First round was a written assignment. Ultimately received a rejection email at 10 pm on a Friday night for the time zone in which I live/in which the office was located. Email appeared to be personalized and local HR lead was cc'd. I understand that they operate offices across multiple time zones, but still don't think this lack of consideration for local timing is a great practice or respectful of candidates.
Interview Questions: Written questions on topical issues.

title: Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions:
I interviewed with GMF in September 2021.

The first step was a phone screening with HR. A week later, I had a zoom interview with the hiring manager. It was all pleasant and straightforward. I was told that I would hear back in “several weeks” but that I could contact them for updates.

They reposted the role multiple times on job search websites over the following weeks. I followed up once and they never responded. It’s nearly December now.

If a candidate is interviewed multiple times, I believe that they deserve a definitive answer, one way or another. I was surprised that GMF ghosted. It’s rude and unprofessional. GMF is a respected organization, and I expected better treatment from them.
Interview Questions: Q: Where do you see yourself in five years?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at German Marshall Fund
Interview Descriptions: Positive, short phone interview. I spoke with several members of the team I would work for, and they asked pretty standard questions about my resume and interest in the position
Interview Questions: Why I was interested in working for the specific department

title: Digital Producer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund
Interview Descriptions:
Very professional interview process. HR communicated me the expectations very well, and the conversations were really engaging.

Interviews went beyond typical competency questions and really try to understand you as a candidate and why you are a good cultural fit for the organization.
Interview Questions:
HR: Break down how you have developed at your previous job. Why is moving to GMF the right path for you now?

Manager: What about our digital channels can be improved? How would you increase engagement with our audiences?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund in Apr 2019
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and received an interview. The first interview was a  brief and not very coherent phone call. The second interview was pushed back twice with rather little notice and held over video chat. In the video chat it seemed as if GMF was unprepared to conduct an interview and the interviewers seemed uninterested in speaking with me. I received a third interview after weeks of hearing nothing--the communication was very poor.
Interview Questions: Company history questions and names of senior management

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: In general, the interview process was simple and straightforward. The first stage is to submit the internship application on time and the following stage is to do a phone interview that asks some basic behavior questions. I heard back on my application status within two weeks.
Interview Questions: Tell me about you and walk me through your resume.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: I applied for this position in July 2017. I interviewed on the phone and received an offer via email later that week. Phone interview was with my direct supervisor and was not difficult.
Interview Questions: What is the biggest issue facing the transatlantic relationship today?

title: Congressional Affairs Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Chicago, IL) in May 2017
Interview Descriptions: I had a preliminary phone interview about the position. The interviewer asked me general questions about my experience and my interest in the role, as well as my academics and extracurriculars.
Interview Questions: Tell me about x experience on your resume.

title: Government Affairs Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in Jul 2016
Interview Descriptions: I received an email from HR asking if I was still interesting and asking for a time to call. I never heard back and sent another email to reschedule the time. After it was not answered I sent to reschedule again. I finally received an email from the HR associate that he was busy and he set up a time to call me the following day. He didn't call and when I reached out, he said he forgot and asked to hold the phone time right then. He scheduled an interview for the following week with the head of the department. She only asked one question: What do you think of Brexit? I was told that I should know the bulk of the information from the announcement and website. She didn't ask any question, but I was to ask them to her. I spent 30 minutes trying to find out more.
Interview Questions: The only question I was asked was what I thought of Brexit.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund in Jun 2016
Interview Descriptions:
They are very slow and not entirely on the ball. I received an email on a Saturday for a Monday phone interview. On Monday I was notified it was an in person interview, so I had to scrap all my plans and race downtown.

Interview itself was more just tell me what you know and see if you have the necessary people skills. Afterwards, I was told to expect a follow-up, which took 2 months.

All together: unprofessional, slow, and inconsiderate.
Interview Questions: Tell me what you know about the program

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund in Apr 2016
Interview Descriptions: The interview was over Skype. It last for about 45 minutes. It started off with the GMF interviewer telling me about what they do, and then asking me various questions to see if my background met her description.
Interview Questions: My experiences within the policy community.

title: Outreach Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and got an email about two weeks later scheduling a phone interview. The interview was pretty basic with questions about the position and why I wished to work at GMF. The interviewer was very friendly, but unfortunately did not answer any of my follow-up emails. I eventually got an email a few weeks later saying I did not get the position.
Interview Questions: Why do you wish to work for the German Marshall Fund?

title: Trainee Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Beijing, Beijing) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions:
First interview with Programme officer, second with transatlantic fellow

Enjoyable experience, first interview asked to demonstrate interests, personal motivation, why you are applying, what you hope to achieve etc. Prepare a few questions of your own 

Second interview was tougher, was asked direct questions about capacity to host forums, admin tasks, also on knowledge and interpretation of significant foreign policy issues. Research needed, expected to give insight/analysis
Interview Questions:
If you were to host a forum on US-China security issues, who would you invite?
What is your general take on US-China relations?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in Jan 2015
Interview Descriptions: I did an over-the-phone interview than an in-person interview for the position. The process felt very casual and felt more like a walk-through of my resume than anything else. I was asked mostly about my experience with planning and logistics support as well as previous research endeavors. It seems that the in-person portion was more of a once-over check than an actual interview.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have with event planning?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions: First a phone interview to conduct standard screening. Second an in-person interview with more of the same questions. The questions were standard and the interviewers were very nice; nothing out of the ordinary.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you helped to plan an event. Describe a time you worked in a team.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund
Interview Descriptions: I applied via their online application and was contacted within two weeks of submitting it. I was first interviewed by two people at GMF over the phone.  After we finished, they asked me to email a writing sample. Two weeks later, I had a second phone interview, where they asked similar questions. Later that day, I received an email saying I was accepted.
Interview Questions: No truly difficult questions. Questions included -- how would you go about research, why GMF, how do you manage your time, etc.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in Sept 2013
Interview Descriptions: About two weeks after the application deadline had passed, I was contacted directly by the program I had applied for by email to set-up a phone interview for the next week. The interview lasted about 30 minutes, and I was given a great overview of the internship program and how I would be evaluated throughout the internship term. By the end of the week I was contacted again via email to set-up an in person interview for the next week. Dress attire was business casual. I was asked to fill out paperwork for HR upon arrival, much of it on contact information for my previous employers. I met with my direct supervisor and their supervisor, and questions were situation/behavioral in nature. I was told I would receive notice of their decision by Friday. At 4:50pm on Friday I received an email congratulating me, and linking me with HR to begin the intake process.
Interview Questions: How would you go about researching the current diplomatic relations between Russia and Georgia?

title: Climate and Energy Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund
Interview Descriptions: It was a pretty standard interview. The supervisor asked about my background and interests at school, in particular my coursework and degree focus. They usually do in person interviews for the interns but since I was not in DC, I did mine over the phone and was offered the position a few days later.
Interview Questions: My supervisor asked me to describe why I thought the program's work was important or especially interesting.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund
Interview Descriptions:
I applied online here twice for different internships, and received one interview, which I believe I only received by name-dropping a fairly prominent professor I had who was close with the organization. I was offered a phone interview a week after my e-mail, which took place a week after that. 

I had a phone interview as I was not in DC, and the whole thing took about 30 minutes and was fairly simple. The interviewer talked for a good 10 minutes about the organization and position itself before starting on my questions. The usual questions were asked, such as: why the GMF, what has prepared me for this position, what would I bring to the position. Then there were some slightly more philosophical questions such as what do I find most important about international relations. My experience with event planning was very important to my interviewer. I was offered the position three weeks after my interview.

They seemed to favor hiring from within and their usual practice was to hire interns after about 6 months; many people in my department had started as interns. However, this may not currently be the case as many former interns who I knew worked there for far longer were offered no advancement after nearly a year of unpaid work. 

I would not recommend assuming that paid employment will be the eventual outcome of your internship, but I learned a great deal about working in a think tank and international relations in general.
Interview Questions: What do I find most interesting about international relations?

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions: The interview process demanded a lot of time, as after two rounds of interviewing and being told I was in the top two candidates, I was asked to write a research paper.  After touching base a few weeks after submission(after no response), I was told that they found someone who better matched the listed job qualifications. I wish they could have somehow been able to tell that I didn't fit the qualifications before having me spend such a large amount of time on the project. I will not be applying again.
Interview Questions: Give us an example of when you managed multiple responsibilities at once.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions: I was asked to explain my interest in the specific focus area for the department that was hiring, including academic experience and personal background relating to the area. Overall the interview was pretty straight-forward. It included the typical questions of what I hoped to do professionally after graduation and how I thought interning at GMF would help my career. I was also warned that the internship included a lot of basic office/administrative tasks, not only research and writing.
Interview Questions: How could my academic research bring an innovative input to the organization.

title: Partnerships Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at German Marshall Fund (Washington, DC) in Jun 2010
Interview Descriptions:
I applied online and was contacted via e-mail not long after my submission to schedule an in-person interview.  I was interviewed by two members of the partnerships team, and later the head of partnerships joined.  Being interviewed 3 on 1 may seem intimidating, but the partnership employees were professional, friendly and able to answer every question I had about the position and GMF.

My best advice to other candidates is to read GMF publications and read about the various programs they coordinate.  It would also be beneficial to know what is currently happening with regard to European-US relations.

To correct some information on the glassdoor website, GMF has way more than 16-50 employees in DC.
Interview Questions: What was your contribution to "Company X"
